ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Besides a comprehensive understanding of the history of laboratories, we also learned to better analyze and explore historical texts.
I improved my reading of sources and research methods.

I developed knowledge about a pretty niche topic in this class, but mostly this class allowed me to develop critical thinking and writing skills, and was a really good practice in connecting scientific history to larger social processes.
Gained an overview of the literature on the spaces of scientific practice and knowledge production in the history and philosophy of science, within broader socio-political and cultural context.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths - engaging texts and discussions
Weaknesses - less focus on the sociological aspects of laboratories.
I really appreciated the way the course was laid out and the way it went through such a variety of information.

The strengths of this course are that it is a topic you're unlikely to study in another class and that you will receive really great, clear feedback. Professor Ramalingam is also really great and helpful, and designs each session with activities/group exercises that make digesting the material a bit easier. The assignments were all reasonable and none of them seemed unnecessary. The major weakness of this class is that the material is sometimes extremely dry, which meant that discussions were sometimes really difficult to engage with.

This is one of the best organized courses I have taken at Yale. The readings were excellent. Prof. Ramalingam facilitated discussions well to encourage coherence of the arguments we collectively formulated but also to allow a diversity of thoughts and opinions. The assignments were clear and helpful for working through the course content in more depth. I appreciated that Prof. Ramalingam consulted the class at multiple points in the semester about how the course was going, and took midterm feedback seriously. The feedback I received in class and on my assignments was very helpful, and Prof. Ramalingam was supportive of each of our ideas and interests.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes - there were a lot of really interesting readings.
If you are really interested in this history, then absolutely. Otherwise, I think this will be a really difficult class to engage with and I don't think you will get much out of it.

I would absolutely recommend this course, regardless of your major or interests. The readings are excellent, Prof. Ramalingam is super knowledgeable and leads great discussions, and the content is varied and offers a ton of opportunity for further reflection and reading. Although the scope is in some sense narrow (the lab seems at the outset to be an oddly specific topic for an entire semester's worth of class), it turns out to be so much more complex than you at first imagine.
